conbody.p: In a tokenized World your wallet is your digital base. It contains your token. It is your account to everything, your daily guide, your digital fault. You will use your wallet daily like you use your mobile phone.

In a tokenized world, the wallet is the user agent. It is an app on a phone, a plugin for the browser, a microchip on a machine. Every human can own as many wallets as he wishes, and wallets can be reproducted on any device.

At the awakening of literacy, there was not the word, but the token. When Babylonian emperors carved runes in tablets of clay they didn't want to say something. They represented material goods and dept. This was when Tokenization started.

A word is a virtual representation of any thing in the physical and imaginated world. It allows to communicate things. Words are free, nobody owns them. A token however represents any thing in the physical and imaginated world in a way that it is not free but owned by someone. A token is a claim on something.

In a world before blockchain, humans had a hard time to protect token against double spends and counterfeits. They made it hart to reproduce a token. By hammering the claim in a stone table, melting it in a crown or in coins, signing the document it is recorded, close the letter with a seal, and so on.

All methods had their shortcoming. Double spend and counterfeit remained epidemic, and only central authorities could narrow its scope. While digitalization gave the written word the ultimate medium in human history, token often have to adhere to outdated medial forms. Tokenization did hardly break the limits of the Babylonian model. It didn't arrive at the digital age yet.
With blockchain, token become truly digitized. A new era of Tokenization has begun. Most people don't know what it means yet.

Any stake in contract is an ownership. Whenever you or someone else signs something, an ownership emerges. A token represents such ownerships. They become digitalized and can be used anywhere on the web for anything.
Like words, token become powerful when they gather.

You have a membership token of your fishing club. With it, you can unlock the clubhouse's door and get a rebate when you pay with your wallet at the local fishing store. If you have a boat driver licence's token too, the membership token can also start the engine of the club's boat. All this happens automatically in your wallet.

You have a subscription token for a magazine. This token allows you to read a few articles of other magazines. You can exchange it against other subscription tokens. If you have a library membership token, you can co-use the library's subscription token to read articles.

You give an employee a one time signing token. He negotiates a deal with a business partner, and when the contract is created as a token, both parties need to provide their signing token, maybe more token, like a company token. Only when the signing token are available, the smart contract of the business relationship can create new token. The smart contract can also define other conditions: It could need a collateral of both parties, which is another token, a proof of being solvent, provided by a token, or a token proofing that a shipment arrived or a product has a clean supply chain. An unlimited number of token can gather, each providing its proof or claim on something. An unlimited number of smart contracts can process and melt the tokens. The payment is made - or an advance - and a token as a claim on a shipment is minted.
